data.text:
110 years ago, on January 12, 1907, was born Sergei Korolev, rocket engineer, Russian scientist-designer of rocket and space systems, full member of the USSR Academy of Sciences (1958, corresponding member since 1953), twice Hero of Socialist Labor (1956, 1961), laureate Lenin Prize(1957); head of the Soviet rocket and space programs, the founder of practical astronautics, and so on and so forth ...

But all these titles and awards might not have been, and only a nameless mound of frozen earth would have remained from Korolev, who miraculously did not die in Stalin's prison and in Kolyma ...

At first, nothing foreshadowed future upheavals and blows of fate: just the childhood of a gifted child in the Russian Empire...

Sergei Korolev was born on January 12, 1907 (according to the new style) in the city of Zhitomir (Russian Empire) in the family of a teacher of Russian literature Pavel Yakovlevich Korolev (1877-1929), originally from Mogilev, and the daughter of a Nizhyn merchant Maria Nikolaevna Moskalenko (Balanina) (1888-1980) ).

House of Korolev in Zhytomyr

He was about three years old when Maria Moskalenko left the family. Little Seryozha was sent to Nizhyn to his grandmother Maria Matveevna and grandfather Nikolai Yakovlevich Moskalenko.

In 1915 he entered the preparatory classes of the gymnasium in Kyiv, in 1917 he went to the first class of the gymnasium in Odessa, where his mother, Maria Nikolaevna Balanina, and stepfather, Grigory Mikhailovich Balanin, moved.

He did not study at the gymnasium for long - it was closed; then there were four months of a unified labor school. Then he was educated at home - his mother and stepfather were teachers, and his stepfather, in addition to teaching, had an engineering education. Also in school years Sergey was interested in the then new aviation technology, and showed exceptional abilities for it. In 1922-1924 he studied at a construction vocational school, studying in many circles and at various courses.

In 1921, he met the pilots of the Odessa hydro detachment and actively participated in aviation public life: from the age of 16 - as a lecturer on the elimination of aviation illiteracy, and from 17 - as the author of the project of a non-motorized K-5 aircraft, officially defended before the competent commission and recommended for construction.

Having entered the Kyiv Polytechnic Institute in 1924 with a degree in aviation technology, Korolev mastered general engineering disciplines in it in two years and became a glider athlete. In the autumn of 1926 he was transferred to the Moscow Higher technical school(MVTU) named after N. E. Bauman.

During his studies at the Moscow Higher Technical School, S.P. Korolev already gained fame as a young capable aircraft designer and an experienced glider pilot. On November 2, 1929, on the glider "Firebird" designed by M. K. Tikhonravov, Korolev passed the exams for the title of "soaring pilot", and in December of the same year, under the guidance of Andrei Nikolaevich Tupolev, he defended his thesis - the project of the SK-4 aircraft. The aircraft he designed and built - the Koktebel and Krasnaya Zvezda gliders and the SK-4 light aircraft, designed to achieve a record flight range - showed Korolev's outstanding abilities as an aircraft designer.

However, especially after meeting with K. E. Tsiolkovsky, Korolev was fascinated by thoughts about flights into the stratosphere and the principles jet propulsion.

In September 1931, S.P. Korolev and a talented enthusiast in the field of rocket engines F.A. Zander achieved the creation in Moscow with the help of Osoaviakhim of a public organization - the Jet Propulsion Study Group (GIRD); in April 1932, it became essentially a state research and design laboratory for the development of missiles. aircraft, in which the first Soviet liquid-propellant ballistic missiles (BR) GIRD-09 and GIRD-10 were created and launched.

On August 17, 1933, the first successful launch of the GIRD rocket was carried out.

In 1933, on the basis of the Moscow GIRD and the Leningrad Gas Dynamics Laboratory (GDL), the Jet Research Institute was established under the leadership of I. T. Kleimenov. Korolev was appointed his deputy with the rank of divinzhener.

Diving engineer S. P. Korolev in 1933

In 1935 he became head of the rocket aircraft department; in 1936, he managed to bring to the test cruise missiles: anti-aircraft - 217 with a powder rocket engine and long-range - 212 with a liquid rocket engine. By 1938, his department had developed projects for long-range liquid cruise and ballistic missiles, aircraft missiles for firing at air and ground targets, and anti-aircraft solid-propellant missiles. However, differences in views on the prospects for the development of rocket technology forced Korolev to leave the post of deputy director, and he was appointed to the ordinary position of senior engineer.

On June 27, 1938, the head of the rocket flying systems department of the Moscow Rocket Research Institute, 31-year-old Sergei Pavlovich Korolev, was arrested under the infamous Article 58 as a member of a counter-revolutionary Trotskyist organization allegedly operating within the RNII, as well as for disrupting the delivery of new types of weapons ( Kleymenov, Langemak, Glushko were arrested earlier in the “RNII case”.

Korolev was tortured during interrogations - both jaws were broken, Sergei Pavlovich was hit on the cheekbone with a decanter. Korolev wrote: “Investigators Shestakov and Bykov subjected me to physical repression and bullying.”

In 1938, the investigators who tortured him, who broke the prisoner's jaw and soon, after threatening to kill his wife and daughter, obtained confessions, hardly thought about the future fate of the person under investigation. Dozens passed through the hands of sadists bright personalities and among the investigators there was even an unspoken competition: who would break down faster and sign everything.

After the arrest. Butyrskaya prison, June 28, 1938

On September 25, 1938, Korolev was included in the list of persons subject to trial by the Military Collegium of the Supreme Court of the USSR. The session of the Military Collegium of the Supreme Court was chaired by the military lawyer Vasily Ulrikh, “through whose hands” tens of thousands of repressed people passed.

The refusal at the trial of the “confessions” knocked out under torture, of course, did not affect anything, but the defendant was lucky. In the list, Korolev was in the first category - almost all of them were sentenced to death. If it had been a year earlier, then everything would have ended for Korolev. But he was lucky, on September 27, 1938, Sergei Korolev was sentenced to 10 years in prison and sent to Kolyma.

In Kolyma, at a gold mine, Korolev survived by accident. To systematic malnutrition and scurvy, severe frosts and exhausting labor, the terror of criminals was added. Criminals generally exploited "enemies of the people" with impunity - at their expense they freed "their own" from hard physical work, took away rations in order to eat better. An attempt at a "rebellion" by a proud loner was easily crushed by starvation. He became a “wick”, they even stopped sending him to work, since he could not walk: “As soon as I bend over, I fall. The tongue was swollen, the gums were bleeding, the teeth were falling out from scurvy.

If you don’t work, they reduce the already beggarly ration. Before an unexpected savior, who recognized a talented colleague, a dying goner appeared: “In inconceivable rags lay a terribly thin, pale, lifeless man.”

Mine Magyak. Korolev spent only five months here, from July to December 1939, he worked at the Maldyak mine in the Susuman region. Among the Kolyma camps, which are already not the most cheerful places, this one had quite notoriety. In 1938-1939, the death rate of prisoners was very high here, and about a year before the future chief designer got there, the “Moscow brigade” of investigators was rampant in Maldyak, of which a certain NKVD lieutenant M. Katselenbogen (Bogen) was especially cruel. Hundreds of people were shot.

“Bogen instructed me and a group of comrades to conduct an investigation, giving three hours to complete 20 cases. When we complained to him about overwork, he directly ordered that the arrested be beaten. Bogen himself set an example for us, summoned one prisoner and beat him with a poker, after which we beat him with whatever we had to. A few days later, Captain Kononovich arrived with prosecutor Metelev at 2 am and by 6 am considered more than 200 cases, of which 133-135 were sentenced to highest measure punishment. The prosecutor did not look at the arrested and did not talk to any of them.”

(from the testimony of an employee of the UNKVD for Dalstroy A. V. Garusor).

On the occasion of the 50th anniversary of Gagarin's flight, a film was made about Korolev, where he was allegedly presented as a rebel against camp orders. In reality, Sergei Pavlovich could hardly stand on his feet from exhaustion, and was not capable of any rebellion. The doctor Tatyana Repeva saved him, transferred him to the hospital as an orderly.

In the autumn of 1940, he was transferred to a new place of detention - the Moscow special prison of the NKVD, where, under the leadership of A.N. Tupolev, also a prisoner, took an active part in the creation of the Pe-2 and Tu-2 bombers and at the same time developed projects for a guided air torpedo and a new version of a missile interceptor.

Getting into Tupolev's sharashka was both salvation and the beginning, without exaggeration, of the greatest deeds. But the phrase "slam without an obituary" became his favorite saying for a long time: “She [Themis] is blindfolded, she will take it and make a mistake, today you decide differential equations, and tomorrow - Kolyma ".

In 1942, Korolev was transferred to another prison-type design bureau at the Kazan Aviation Plant, where work was underway on new types of rocket engines to be used in aviation. Korolev devotes himself to this work with his characteristic enthusiasm. He was released in 1944 and rehabilitated in April 1957.

But the arrest and stay in the Gulag forever infected Korolev with a pessimistic attitude towards the surrounding reality. According to the recollections of people who knew him closely, Sergei Pavlovich's favorite saying was the phrase "Slapped without an obituary."

In July 1944, S.P. Korolev was released early from prison with the removal of a criminal record but without rehabilitation (minutes of the meeting of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR on July 27, 1944) on the personal instructions of I.V. Stalin, after which he worked for another year in Kazan.

On May 13, 1946, Decree of the Council of Ministers of the USSR No. 1017-419ss “Issues of rocket weapons” appears, S.P. Korolev is not directly mentioned in the text of the Decree, but in accordance with this document he was appointed to a new place of work. In August 1946, he was appointed Chief Designer of the Special Design Bureau No. 1 (OKB-1), created in Kaliningrad near Moscow, to develop long-range ballistic missiles, and head of department No. 3 of NII-88 for their development.

The first task set by the government for S.P. Korolev, as the Chief Designer of OKB-1, and all organizations involved in missile weapons, was to create an analogue of the V-2 rocket from Soviet materials. But already in 1947, a decree was issued on the development of new ballistic missiles with a greater range than the V-2, up to 3000 km.

In 1948, S.P. Korolev began flight and design tests of the R-1 ballistic missile (an analogue of the V-2) and in 1950 successfully put it into service.

In 1956, under the leadership of S.P. Korolev, a two-stage intercontinental ballistic missile R-7 was created with a detachable warhead weighing 3 tons and a flight range of 8 thousand km. The rocket was successfully tested in 1957 at test site No. 5 built for this purpose in Kazakhstan (the current Baikonur cosmodrome). For the combat duty of these missiles in 1958-1959, a combat launch station (the Angara object) was built near the village of Plesetsk (Arkhangelsk Region, the current Plesetsk cosmodrome). A modification of the R-7A missile with a range increased to 11,000 km was in service with the USSR Strategic Missile Forces from 1960 to 1968.

In 1957, Sergei Pavlovich created the first ballistic missiles on stable fuel components (mobile land and sea based); he became a pioneer in these new and important directions in the development of missile weapons.

On October 4, 1957, the first artificial Earth satellite in the history of mankind was launched into low Earth orbit. His flight was a stunning success and created a high international prestige for the Soviet Union.

April 12, 1961 S.P. Korolev again strikes the world community. Having created the first manned spacecraft "Vostok-1", he implements the world's first manned flight into space - a citizen of the USSR Yuri Alekseevich Gagarin in near-Earth orbit.

The main achievement of the USSR was the first space flight. Communists often cite Gagarin's flight as an example to prove the superiority of the Soviet system. Under the leadership of S.P. Korolev in the USSR, ballistic and geophysical rockets, artificial Earth satellites, launch vehicles and manned spaceships"Vostok" and "Voskhod", on which for the first time in history a man's space flight and man's exit into outer space were made. Rocket and space systems, at the head of the development of which was Korolev, made it possible for the first time in the world to carry out launches of artificial satellites of the Earth and the Sun, flights of automatic interplanetary stations to the Moon, Venus, Mars, to make a soft landing on the surface of the Moon. Under his leadership, artificial Earth satellites of the Elektron and Molniya-1 series, satellites of the Kosmos series, interplanetary vehicles of the Zond series were created.

But in fact, Korolev as a designer took place in many respects not thanks to, but in spite of the Soviet regime. The Soviet government almost rotted him in the camps. The fact that Korolev survived is just an accident. If the circumstances had turned out a little differently, there would have been no Gagarin's flight. Had Korolev fallen into the clutches of Katselenbogen or not met a good doctor, and instead of Gagarin's flight, we would have had an unmarked grave of the Kolyma ZK.

Ultimately, Korolev died prematurely thanks to Stalin's executioners. premature death Koroleva in 1966 was the hardest blow for the whole industry. The last attempt to save the patient was the operation, which was personally carried out by the Minister of Health of the USSR. During the operation, the anesthesiologist encountered an unforeseen circumstance - in order to give anesthesia, it was necessary to insert a tube, and the operated person could not open his mouth wide. The patient's jaws, broken during the interrogation, did not heal properly, and he was always nervous before visiting the dentist...

Corresponding Member of the USSR Academy of Sciences S. N. Efuni spoke about the 1966 operation, during which Sergei Pavlovich died. Efuni himself took part in it only at a certain stage, but, being at that time the leading anesthesiologist of the 4th Main Directorate of the USSR Ministry of Health, he knew all the details of this tragic event.

— Anesthetist Yuri Ilyich Savinov encountered an unforeseen circumstance- said Sergei Naumovich. - In order to give anesthesia, it was necessary to insert a tube, and Korolev could not open his mouth wide. He had fractures of two jaws ...

- Did Sergei Pavlovich have a broken jaw?- the journalist Y. Golovanov asked Korolev's wife, Nina Ivanovna.

He never mentioned it she answered thoughtfully. — He really could not open his mouth wide, and I remember: when he had to go to the dentist, he was always nervous ...

From the official death certificate:

Tov. S.P. Korolev was ill with sarcoma of the rectum. In addition, he had: atherosclerotic cardiosclerosis, sclerosis of the cerebral arteries, pulmonary emphysema and metabolic disorders. S.P. Korolev underwent an operation to remove the tumor with extirpation of the rectum and part of the sigmoid colon. The death of comrade S.P. Koroleva came from heart failure (acute myocardial ischemia).

Why so many diseases at the age of 60? Korolev received emphysema in camps in Kolyma and the Far East.

In 1965, shortly before the death of the great designer, he was visited by friends from the Tupolev sharashka. Pointing to the guard at the gate, he, an academician, twice Hero of Socialist Labor, said: “You know, guys, sometimes you wake up at night, lie down and think: now, maybe someone has already been found, gave the command - and these same polite guards will brazenly enter here and say: “Come on, bastard, pack your things!”

But this was already after Stalin and Khrushchev, in the era of the “good” Brezhnev. By the way, the Nazi designer "V" Wernher von Braun received American citizenship earlier (1955) than Korolev, who had not committed crimes, was rehabilitated (1957).

Forever ruined life. And no awards and titles could compensate for the torment and suffering that the future General Designer endured in Stalin's dungeons ...

"said Alla Medvedeva, scientific secretary of the academic readings on cosmonautics. The patriarch of Russian cosmonautics did not live until his 100th birthday only two and a half months.

According to Medvedeva, Boris Chertok died on Friday at 07:40 am. Colleagues of the academician will inform about the place and time of the farewell ceremony later.

For many years, Boris Chertok was the head of the preparation and conduct of academic lectures on astronautics. They are known to many as the "Royal Readings". Before last days the outstanding designer remained an employee of RSC Energia and gave lectures to students.

Alexei Leonov, twice Hero of the USSR, the first person to travel in outer space, commenting on the sad news, said: " Last Man, which connected us with the era of S.P. The Queen has passed away. With the departure of Boris Evseevich, unfortunately, the era of great domestic space achievements is also leaving. This is great sadness. Sorry man. Kind, smart, powerful - because the weak do not live up to a hundred years. I suggested making a film about Boris Evseevich while he was alive. Unfortunately, we didn't make it. With his departure, a true witness to the heyday of the great space state was lost.

"Together with Korolev, Chertok sorted through German archives, recreating bit by bit the V-2 rocket in the USSR. This rocket formed the basis of domestic ballistic missiles and the legendary Seven, which is the prototype of the current Soyuz. He participated in the creation of the first artificial satellite Earth, Salyutov, Voskhodov, Vostokov, all automatic lunar stations, Buran reusable spacecraft, Leonov recalled.

Chertok about his dream and the secret code for Gagarin

The name of Boris Evseevich is associated with the main achievements of the Soviet Union in space exploration. He always willingly shared memories of the events of the past. So, in an interview Russian newspaper", given 7 years ago, Chertok admitted that flying into space was his dream, revealed the reasons for the loss in the "moon race" of the Soviet Union to the Americans, spoke about the secret code for Gagarin.

The academician also spoke about the first meeting with Korolev, which took place in Germany in 1945. Chertok at that time was the head of the Rabe Institute. The main goal of the institute was the restoration of German rocket technology. “Once they called from Berlin: “Lieutenant Colonel Korolev will come to you.” I remember, when I saw his very shabby Opel-Cadet, I immediately thought: “It’s a small bird ...”, Chertok said, smiling. At the same time, he noted that Korolev Chertok, describing the character of Korolyov, noted that in strong terms he was never shy, but at the same time very quickly retreated.

Chertok also expressed the opinion in an interview that the Soviet Union could not send its cosmonauts to the Moon first, because it refused to ground test the first stage of the N-1 launch vehicle. "To carry out the tests, it was necessary to build a very expensive and huge firing stand. It was decided not to build it. Therefore, constructive, design, technological miscalculations appeared at the launches. If ground tests had been carried out, they would have appeared even then," the academician explained.

The point in the "Lunar program", according to him, was put by three people: Mstislav Keldysh - President of the Academy of Sciences, Sergei Afanasyev - Minister of General Engineering and Dmitry Ustinov - Secretary of the CPSU Central Committee for Defense Affairs. They decided that after four unsuccessful launches, there was no point in continuing the "moon race". By that time, Korolev had already died, and Vasily Mishin took the place of the chief designer. Although the developers proposed the construction of a base on the Moon, the Trinity did not agree with them. Therefore, the project was not implemented.

The interview also talked about the flight of Yuri Gagarin. "Of course, we risked a lot by launching Gagarin. True, it should be noted that the Americans, following us, showed great courage: the reliability of launching a man into space on Mercury was worse," the academician said.

Boris Chertok told the following about the reasons for assigning the secret code 125 to Gagarin: “According to psychologists, a person who found himself face to face with the Universe could “go nuts.” Therefore, someone suggested introducing a digital code lock for the first flight. Only by typing "125", it was possible to use the power supply of the manual control system."

According to Boris Evseevich, this code was sealed in an envelope. “It was assumed that if Gagarin could get the envelope and, after reading it, dial the code, then he was of his mind and could take over manual control. code to Gagarin," he said.

Journalists at the end of the interview asked Boris Evseevich if he ever wanted to go into space himself. He honestly replied that he wanted to, but ironically added that at his age "it would be a completely justified risk."

In another interview that Boris Chertok gave to the magazine " Russian space"(which was published this spring on the website of Roskomos), he regretted that so far, earthlings in the Universe have not found comrades in mind.

“I am 99 years old and I am satisfied that I was involved in events of historical significance. However, it is sad to realize that we are alone in the foreseeable space. The Hubble telescope has discovered a large number of exoplanets, but nowhere necessary conditions for the origin of life. Today, the only hope for Jupiter's moon is Europa. There, under the ice shell, there are supposedly oceans of water. Perhaps they can find traces of life there. However, for the time being, the mind is peculiar only to the inhabitant of the planet Earth - to man," the academician said.

Boris Evseevich Chertok. Biography

Boris Evseevich was born in Lodz (Poland) on March 1, 1912. He graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute in 1940. In the period from 1940 to 1945 he worked in the Design Bureau of Chief Designer Viktor Bolkhovitinov.

Chertok as part of a special The commission was sent to Germany in April 1945. Until January 1947, Chertok was the head of a group of Soviet specialists who studied FAU missiles. Boris Chertok and Alexey Isaev in the same year organized in Thuringia (in the Soviet occupation zone) a joint Soviet-German institute "Rabe". The main focus of the work was the study and development of control technology for long-range ballistic missiles. On the basis of the institute, a new institute was created - "Nordhausen". Sergei Korolev was appointed chief engineer of this institute.

Boris Chertok from that time worked closely with Korolev. In 1946, Boris Evseevich was transferred to the post of deputy. chief engineer and head of the department of control systems NII-88 (Scientific Research Institute N88) of the Ministry of Armaments. Chertok in 1950 was appointed deputy head, and in 1951 head of the control systems department of OKB-1 NII-88 (Special Design Bureau N1, today RSC Energia). Korolev was the chief designer.

In 1974 Chertok was appointed deputy. General Designer for Control Systems NPO Energia. Since 1946, his scientific and engineering activities have been associated with the development and creation of control systems for spacecraft and rockets.

Chertok was the leader in the creation of the school, which to this day determines the scientific directions, as well as the level domestic technology for manned space flights.

In 1961, B. Chertok received the title of Hero of Socialist Labor, was elected a corresponding member of the USSR Academy of Sciences in the Department of Mechanics and Control Processes in 1968, a full member of the Russian Academy of Sciences - in 2000, a full member International Academy astronautics - in 1990

Chertok's work has received numerous awards. He received two Orders of Lenin (1956, 1961), in 1971 - the Order October revolution, in 1975 - the Red Banner of Labor, in 1945 - the Red Star, in 1996 - "For Merit to the Fatherland" IV degree, in 1992 - the Boris Petrov Gold Medal of the Russian Academy of Sciences, in 2008 - the Sergei Korolev Gold Medal of the Russian Academy of Sciences.

In addition, Boris Evseevich was a laureate of the Lenin Prize (1957) for participation in the creation of the first artificial satellites of the Earth, and a laureate of the State Prize of the USSR (1976) for participation in the implementation of the Soyuz-Apollo project.

At the end of 2011, Academician Chertok was awarded the International Prize of St. Andrew the First-Called "For Faith and Loyalty" for his outstanding contribution to the development and development of rocket and space science and industry in Russia.

At the beginning of the era of astronautics, Sergei Pavlovich Korolev gathered the best personnel throughout the country for an enterprise that would determine the fate of our country for centuries to come. These people became the same legendary designers who launched a man into space, opening a new chapter in the life of mankind. Where did they live? After all, they and their families could not live permanently in the most difficult conditions of Baikonur?

The quarter between Frunze, Tsiolkovsky, Karl Marx and Lesnaya streets became the first post-war quarter to be rebuilt in Podlipki - in the central part of the city

Among the inhabitants of the quarter you can find:

1. General Designer of OKB-1;

2. The closest associates and friends of Sergei Pavlovich Korolev;

3. Employees of party, state and local authorities;

4. Honorary citizens of the city.

For example,

Vasily Pavlovich Mishin- Rocket constructor space technology. One of the founders of Soviet practical cosmonautics. Colleague of S.P. Korolev, who continued his work in the field of astronautics. General Designer of OKB-1 (OKB-1 - TsKBEM, later - NPO Energia); Hero of Socialist Labor; Laureate of the Lenin and State Prizes of the USSR; Honored Inventor of the RSFSR; Academician of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR; Member of the International Academy of Astronautics; Lecturer at the Department of Design and Construction of Spacecraft at the Moscow Aviation Institute named after Sergo Ordzhonikidze.

Alexei Mikhailovich Isaev- Soviet design engineer, associate of S.P. Koroleva, creator of liquid rocket engines, chief designer of Separate Design Bureau No. 2 (later KB KHIMMASH). Invented a liquid-propellant rocket engine of a closed cycle. Hero of Socialist Labor. Laureate of the Lenin Prize.

Leonid Alexandrovich Voskresensky- Deputy Korolev for testing, Soviet rocket technology test scientist, one of the closest associates of S.P. Korolev, professor, doctor of technical sciences. In 1954-1963, L. A. Voskresensky was the deputy chief designer of OKB-1 (the chief designer was S. P. Korolev). Participated in the unique development and testing of domestic rocket artillery and rocket and space technology, supervised the launches of all types of missiles developed during this period in OKB-1, including the first intercontinental combat missiles 8K71 (R-7), 8K74 (R-7A) and 8K75 (R-9, R-9A), capable of carrying a nuclear charge, as well as space launch vehicles 8K72 (Vostok) and 8K78 (Molniya)

Anatoly Petrovich Abramov- one of the leading specialists in ground equipment of rocket and space technology of the Soviet Union, diplomat, doctor of technical sciences, professor, laureate of the Lenin Prize, associate of Sergei Pavlovich Korolev. Laureate of the Lenin Prize; Doctor of Technical Sciences; Professor of the Moscow Aviation Institute named after Sergo Ordzhonikidze; mechanical engineer; Head of Department, Head of the Complex, Deputy Chief (General) Designer of OKB-1 (Central Design Bureau of Experimental Engineering, Research and Production Association "Energy"); supervisor thematic direction, Senior Researcher,

scientific consultant of the Rocket and Space Corporation Energia named after S.P. Koroleva"; specialist in ground equipment and experimental testing of ground launch complexes.

Viktor Mikhailovich Klyucharev- first Deputy CEO NPO Energia; director of the Experimental Machine Building Plant (ZEM), first deputy head of TsKBEM; chief engineer - deputy director of plant 88; He was directly involved in the organization and preparation of production, the development of manufacturing technologies for the first domestic long-range ballistic missiles and launch vehicles, the first domestic automatic space stations and satellites, space systems under the programs of manned spacecraft "Vostok", "Voskhod", "Soyuz", lunar programs L1 and N1-L3, programs of the first orbital stations "Salyut", space upper stages D and DM Laureate of the State Prize (1976), awarded the Order of the Red Star (1945), the Red Banner of Labor (1956), Lenin (1957, 1961), the October Revolution (1971), medals "For Valiant Labor in the Great Patriotic war 1941-1945" (1946), "In memory of the 800th anniversary of Moscow" (1947), three gold and one silver medals VDNH.

Igor Nikolaevich Sadovsky- designer of solid-propellant rockets and Energia launch vehicle. Last years before OKB-1, he worked in the apparatus of the Council of Ministers, and then in the Ministry of Medium Machine Building - the Atomic Ministry. But he was again very drawn to rocketry. He realized that the apparatus activity was not for him. He quickly agreed with Korolev and was appointed deputy to Svyatoslav Lavrov, head of the design and ballistic department. Sadovsky persuaded volunteers and assembled a small "illegal" group to prepare proposals for solid fuel ballistic missiles (BRTTs). The main core is three young specialists: Verbin, Sungurov and Titov. Later, Igor Nikolaevich Sadovsky was appointed chief designer of the modernized solid-propellant rocket of the 8K98P complex.

This is only 6 people, but in fact there are about 30 of them. Everyone deserves at least a commemorative plaque. Click on the image to open it in full size.

They want to demolish the quarter where these great people lived because the houses there are old and too lazy to repair them. Residents of the quarter (4 people) and city activists (3 people) wrote an album about the history of the quarter, which was submitted to the Administration, the Council of Deputies, the Head of the city, local residents. Because of "No money, but you hold on" It is easier for the administration to demolish and build new and nice houses than to reconstruct the old ones following the example of house No. 15.

Now, not a single building in the quarter is included in either the list of dilapidated housing stock or the list of emergency stock. Recently, the Head of the Queen came to the quarter to communicate with residents, and then wrote on his Instagram "Following the instructions of Governor Andrey Vorobyov @andreyvorobiev, I held a meeting with residents of the historical center of our city, Frunze and Lesnaya St.", thus recognizing its historical value, however, neither in the plots of "Korolev-tv" nor in the plots of the "360" channel was there ever mentioned either a historical center or a word about famous residents, plots in the style "All for demolition" are shown even those who are against it. If the quarter is a historical center, then its fate is the interest of all residents of the city, without exception.

Yesterday they demolished (and thank God) the wood sheds that were built 70 years ago. Surely they will make a parking lot or a playground there, which is certainly good, because 5 months ago no one wanted to deal with some two-story buildings in the depths of a quarter of the historical center of the city. Now the situation has changed.

In 1926, after studying for two years at the KPI, Sergei Korolev transferred to Moscow to a special evening group in aeromechanics at the Moscow Higher Technical School. During the day he worked either in a design bureau or at an aircraft factory, and in the evening he studied. By this time, his mother and stepfather had moved to Moscow.

With all his might, Korolev strove for aviation. As soon as he entered the Moscow Higher Technical School, Sergey immediately joined the work of the student circle AKNEZH - Academic Circle. Nikolai Egorovich Zhukovsky. Engineers and scientists gave lectures there.

Aviation spread its wings wider and wider. The youth passionately rushed to the sky. In January 1927, the solemn opening of the Moscow glider school took place in the Gorki Leninskiye area. In March 1927, Sergei graduated with honors from the glider school. One thing he has already achieved, he learned to fly a glider. Further, his task was to gain knowledge and ... build aircraft.

With particular impatience, Sergei Korolev waited for the lectures of the then-famous thirty-five-year-old aviation designer Andrei Nikolaevich Tupolev. He taught students a course on aircraft engineering. For students, Andrei Nikolaevich is an indisputable authority. After all, his planes had already plowed the sky by that time.

Tsiolkovsky "Research of world spaces by jet devices". Books, drawings, diagrams, handicraft models - everything that was shown at the exhibition touched Korolev's mind. Since that time, he has become more focused on rockets and space flights.

However, all his thoughts were still absorbed by planes and gliders. In September 1929, Sergei Korolev and his colleague Sergei Lyushin presented an unusual glider at the VI All-Union Gliding Competition in Koktebel, about 50-90 kg heavier than their counterparts. At the time, it was believed that the smaller the glider, the better. A test flight on the Koktebel was made by K.K. Artseulov, reporting to the members technical committee: “The airframe is well balanced. Handles well. May be allowed to fly." On the Koktebel glider, twenty-two-year-old Korolev set a soaring record. He hovered in the air for more than four hours.

In October 1930, at the All-Union meeting of glider pilots S.P. Korolev came out with a new SK-3 glider, which he called the Red Star. However, it was on it that, for the first time in the history of aviation, test pilot V.A. Stepanchenok, an experienced glider pilot, made the famous Nesterov's loop in free flight.

Korolev was not present at the competitions, he was suddenly struck down by severe typhus. As a result of a complication, severe headaches appeared, and a craniotomy operation was required. She was successful, but remained a difficult test not only for Sergei, but for everyone who loved him.

After the illness, the body of the Queen was so weakened that he had to leave work for several months. But as soon as it became easier, Sergei enthusiastically set to work K.E. Tsiolkovsky "Jet Airplane".

S. Korolev was still interested in aviation, but the desire to find means to fly higher, faster, farther led him to the idea of ​​​​investigating the possibilities of jet propulsion. He agreed with K.E. Tsiolkovsky: "The era of propeller-driven airplanes should be followed by the era of jet airplanes, or stratospheric airplanes."

On May 13, 1946, a decision was made to create in the USSR an industry for the development and production of rocket weapons with liquid rocket engines. In accordance with the same resolution, it was planned to unite all groups of Soviet engineers for the study of German V-2 rocket weapons, who had worked in Germany since 1945, into a single Nordhausen Research Institute, whose director was Major General L.M. Gaidukov, and S.P. Korolev as chief engineer-technical manager. In Germany, Sergei Pavlovich not only studies the German V-2 rocket, but also designs a more advanced ballistic missile with a range of up to 600 km.

Soon, all Soviet specialists will return to the Soviet Union to the research institutes and experimental design bureaus created in accordance with the above-mentioned May government decree. In August 1946, S.P. Korolev was appointed chief designer of long-range ballistic missiles and head of department No. 3 of NII-88 for their development.

The first task set by the government for S.P. Korolev as the chief designer and all organizations involved in rocket weapons was to create an analogue of the V-2 rocket from domestic materials.

But already in 1947, a decree was issued on the development of new ballistic missiles with a greater range than the V-2: up to 3000 km. In 1948, S.P. Korolev begins flight and design tests of the R-1 ballistic missile (an analogue of the V-2) and in 1950 successfully puts it into service. This rocket differed from the German one in much greater reliability.

In parallel, S.P. Korolev is developing a new V-2 ballistic missile with a range of 600 km. The R-2 rocket had a carrying fuel tank, a more convenient layout for operation and, most importantly, a warhead that separated in flight. In addition, the rocket propulsion system was significantly improved in order to increase its thrust, and the autonomous control system had twice the accuracy of fire. The R-2 missile was put into service in 1951, i.e., only a year later than the R-1 missile.

Together with practical work on rocket weapons at NII-88, under the scientific guidance of S. I. Korolev, large-scale design and experimental studies were launched on topics H-I, H-2, H-3 in order to create a scientific and technical reserve for the development of qualitatively new ballistic missiles.

On the topic H-1 were carried out experimentally - theoretical studies of the main technical problems associated with the implementation of the R-3 rocket project, which has a flight range of 3000 km: it was necessary to ensure the stability of the rocket flight without a stabilizer (aerodynamically unstable) circuit and to obtain data on the behavior of boiling liquid oxygen in a thermally uninsulated oxidizer carrier tank during movement on the active section of the trajectory at increased external heat fluxes into the mass of liquid oxygen. On the basis of the design solutions of the R-2 rocket with the use of its forced engine, a single-stage experimental BR R-ZA was created without a stabilizer circuit with a flight range of 1200 km. Successful flight tests of this missile gave grounds to the Ministry of Defense to accept it into service in 1956 with a nuclear warhead as the R-5M. It was the first domestic strategic missile, which became the basis of the country's nuclear missile shield.

On the topic H-2, studies were carried out on the possibility and expediency of creating ballistic missiles operating on stable high-boiling fuel components (using nitric acid with nitrogen oxides as an oxidizer). As a result, the possibility of creating such missiles was confirmed and a preliminary design of the first Russian BR R-11 with a range of 250 km and a launch weight half that of the R-1 was completed. However, taking into account the environmental toxicity of nitric oxides and the lower energy characteristics of a stable liquid fuel compared to fuel based on liquid oxygen and kerosene, as well as the resulting serious problems With the development of rocket engines with the required thrust (greater than 8 tons) that operate stably on these fuel components, it was found expedient to use a nitric acid oxidizer with nitrogen oxides for ballistic missiles with a relatively short flight range. When creating rockets with a longer flight range, and especially intercontinental ones, it was recommended to use liquid oxygen as an oxidizer. Sergey Pavlovich proved to be faithful to this direction of development of rocket technology throughout his entire creative activity.

The Ministry of Defense instructed OKB-1 NII-88 to develop the N-11 rocket, and S. P. Korolev brilliantly solved this problem by using the 8-ton engine A. M. Isaev had just created for an anti-aircraft missile and for the first time using a liquid pressure accumulator for supply fuel into the combustion chamber.

On the basis of the R-11, S.P. Korolev developed and put into service in 1957 the R-11M strategic missile with a nuclear warhead, transported in a refueled form on a tank chassis. Having seriously modified this missile, he adapted it for arming submarines (PL) as the R-11FM. The changes were more than serious, as was done new system control and aiming, as well as the possibility of firing at a fairly strong excitement seas from the surface position of the submarine, i.e. with strong pitching. Thus, Sergei Pavlovich created the first ballistic missiles on stable mobile ground and sea-based fuel components and was a pioneer in these new and important directions in the development of missile weapons.

Being engaged in combat ballistic missiles, S.P. Korolev, as it is now clear, strove for more - for the conquest of outer space and human space flights. To this end, back in 1949, Sergei Pavlovich, together with scientists from the USSR Academy of Sciences, began research using modifications of the R-1A rocket by regularly launching them vertically to altitudes of up to 100 km, and then using more powerful R-2 and R-5 rockets to altitudes of 200 and 500 km, respectively. The purpose of these flights was to study the parameters of near space, solar and galactic radiation, the Earth's magnetic field, the behavior of highly developed animals in space conditions (weightlessness, overloads, large vibrations and acoustic loads), as well as the development of life support means and the return of animals to Earth from space - about seven dozen such launches were made. With this, Sergei Pavlovich laid in advance serious foundations for the assault on space by man.

In 1955, long before the flight tests of the R-7 rocket, S. P. Korolev, M. V. Keldysh, M. K. Tikhonravov went to the government with a proposal to launch an artificial Earth satellite (AES ).

The government supports this initiative. In August 1956, OKB-1 left the NII-88 and became an independent organization, the chief designer and director of which was S.P. Korolev. And already on October 4, 1957, S.P. Korolev launches the first satellite in the history of mankind into a near-Earth orbit. His flight is a stunning success and creates a high international prestige for our country.

Sergei Pavlovich is in no hurry to solve the problem of human space exploration. The first spacecraft made only one orbit: no one knew how a person would feel during such a long weightlessness, what psychological stresses would act on him during an unusual and unexplored space travel. Following the first flight of Yu. A. Gagarin on August 6, 1961, German Stepanovich Titov made a second space flight on the Vostok-2 spacecraft, which lasted one day. Again - a rigorous analysis of the influence of flight conditions on the functioning of the body. Then the joint flight of the spacecraft "Vostok-3" and "Vostok-4", piloted by cosmonauts A. N. Nikolaev and P. R. Popovich, from August 11 to 12, 1962; direct radio communication was established between the astronauts. The following year—the joint flight of cosmonauts VF Bykovsky and VV Tereshkova on the Vostok-5 and Vostok-6 spacecraft from June 14 to 16, 1963—the possibility of a woman's flight in space is being studied. Behind them, from October 12 to 13, 1964, in space was a crew of three people of various specialties: a ship commander, a flight engineer, and a doctor on the more complex Voskhod spacecraft. On March 18, 1965, during a flight on the Voskhod-2 spacecraft with a crew of two, cosmonaut A. A. Leonov makes the world's first spacewalk in a spacesuit through an airlock.

Tracking the series of accomplished space flights, one cannot fail to notice a clear methodological sequence of human space exploration and preparation for the creation of a scientific manned long-term orbital station (DOS), the need for which S.P. Korolev spoke at the beginning of the space assault.

Continuing to develop the program of manned near-Earth flights, Sergei Pavlovich begins to implement his ideas on the development of a manned DOS. Its prototype was a fundamentally new, more advanced than the previous ones, Soyuz spacecraft. This spacecraft included a utility compartment, where the astronauts could spend a long time without space suits and conduct scientific research. During the flight, the automatic docking of two Soyuz spacecraft in orbit and the transfer of cosmonauts from one ship to another through outer space in spacesuits were also envisaged. Unfortunately, Sergei Pavlovich did not live to see the implementation of his ideas in the Soyuz spacecraft.

Responding to space success of the Soviet Union in the field of manned flights and wanting to restore its technical authority, the United States is adopting the Apollo program, fantastic in terms of goals and scope of work, which consists in creating a lunar space complex that will ensure the landing of two cosmonauts on the moon. In parallel with the rapid development of manned cosmonautics, work is underway on satellites for scientific, national economic and defense purposes. In 1958, a geophysical satellite was developed and put into space, and then the Elektron paired satellites to study the Earth's radiation belts. In 1959, three automatic spacecraft were created and launched to the Moon. The first and second were for the delivery of the pennant of the Soviet Union to the Moon, the third for the purpose of photographing the far (invisible) side of the Moon. Subsequently, S.P. Korolev began to develop a more advanced lunar apparatus for its soft landing on the surface of the Moon, photographing and transmitting a lunar panorama to Earth (object E-6).
